13.24.text:
Christopher Rowell:– Now this is going to
be a bit of a ragbag I think compared to some

16.49.text:
of the previous, more precise talks. And as
David says, the chief character is the 6th

26.71.text:
Duke of Devonshire who I’m writing, well
I have written, a chapter about him for the

35.43.text:
new Hardwick book. And he’s become rather
a favourite of mine I have to say. Here he

39.87.text:
is in a rather interesting portrait by an
artist that I’ve never heard of before,

46.27.text:
called Orazio Manara, who’s obviously known
as Horace in England. That is only from NT

54.66.text:
collections online but I presume it’s correct.
He’s a Parmese artist and there is a pendant

61.74.text:
to this portrait of the lady who called herself
the Countess of Newburgh. In fact the title

72.44.text:
was deemed to have become extinct on the attainder
of one of her predecessors, or her husband’s

79.80.text:
predecessors. But the Duke was very fond of
both of them and the husband died in 1831.

84.81.text:
And normally if you see a pair of portraits
you think of a man and wife but this is actually

92.47.text:
the Duke and his friend.
And he went in for these amitié amoureuse.

99.90.text:
He’s a very enigmatic figure. He left voluminous
diaries, which are in the archives at Chatsworth,

110.01.text:
and I have been through quite a few of them.
Fortunately a lot of them have been transcribed

115.69.text:
because his handwriting is very difficult
to decipher. What’s rather frustrating is

120.85.text:
that somebody has been through some of the
more juicy bits with an impenetrable black

126.12.text:
pen, and one is just poised in one case to
learn what happened in the conservatory in

137.01.text:
Rome with Princess Pauline Borghese. And he
says Pauline and I went in to the Orangery

147.97.text:
and…!
The other thing which is quite amusing was

152.89.text:
that he was a great patron of sculptors, Canova
in particular. Rushed back to Rome when Canova

159.98.text:
died and bought up Canova statuary, which
you can see in the Chatsworth sculpture gallery.

168.67.text:
But he also employed a sculptor called Thomas
Campbell and plaster relics of Pauline’s

175.21.text:
anatomy were required. And this was not the
only example of people being fascinated by

183.74.text:
her anatomy because in the Musée des Arts
Décoratifs in Paris, there is actually a

188.31.text:
gilt bronze cup by Jean Baptiste Odiot of
her breast which has been made into a drinking

196.54.text:
cup. We do hear that on the 2nd of March 1824,
‘Chez Pauline in bed, the lovely foot’,

208.17.text:
and then the black line comes in. But you
must read Jim Lees-Milne’s excellent biography.

217.30.text:
There’s also a book by somebody called Pearson,
called ‘Serpents…

224.65.text:
David Taylor:–‘Stags and Serpents’.
Christopher Rowell:– ‘Stags and Serpents’,

230.15.text:
which has a very good chapter about the 6th
Duke and is written in a very trenchant sort

236.18.text:
of way. He was, as you see, a knight at the
Garter but then being Duke of Devonshire,

242.81.text:
that wasn’t really unexpected. He was a
great Whig aristocrat and his… He was immensely

253.60.text:
rich, although his friend Sir Joseph Paxton
had to sort out the million pound debt that

260.75.text:
was burdening the estates by selling Londesborough
and Baldersby in Yorkshire.

268.00.text:
He came from a completely chaotic and shambolic
family background. His parents lived famously

275.23.text:
in a ménage à trois. He… His family though
was a very warm group. And although you could

286.47.text:
describe him as a solitary epicurean who was
happiest on his own arranging his books or

292.98.text:
rearranging his pictures, he did have a great
interest in his friends. He had mistresses

299.83.text:
rather than wives, and he liked his independence.
He entertained hugely at Chatsworth.

307.78.text:
What’s very interesting is that Hardwick
was the place where you got into a britzka

315.14.text:
or some other form of carriage and you were
driven across, and the Duke would show you

319.46.text:
around the house. He was very proud of Hardwick
and I think he, as David hinted earlier, he…

326.79.text:
He looked on it with a sort of antiquarian
interest. Now it’s interesting that – it’s

335.63.text:
symmetrical - that he died (his dates incidentally
are 1790 to 1858), he died at Hardwick in

344.43.text:
the same room as his ancestress Bess of Hardwick.
And Mark Girouard has very perceptively pointed

356.56.text:
out that it’s very very difficult to completely
understand, and I think that this book will

366.76.text:
bring that out to a much greater extent than
it has ever been achieved. Just, you know,

374.36.text:
his presence is everywhere at Hardwick, like
Bess’s. He tried… He did all sort of things

379.18.text:
here, both architecturally and in terms of
the display of the collection. And I think

385.23.text:
that you could say that his death brought
to a close the second great period of this

389.77.text:
house. And that more than any other of his
predecessors after Bess’s reign, he put

396.46.text:
his mark on the house just as he did in Chatsworth.
Now this is his portrait by Archer Shee and

413.86.text:
this is the portrait that it’s recorded
that it was painted while he was at Harrow

421.44.text:
and it was given to his schoolmaster who gave
it back to him after… His widow gave it

429.44.text:
back to the Duke after his schoolmaster’s
death. This is the cycle of leaving portraits

435.18.text:
that you find at Eton, where in that case
the headmaster got the portraits and on…

441.64.text:
On the death of the headmaster the pictures
would come back to the school. But this came

447.25.text:
back to him and what’s very touching is
that on the night of his death he was dining

454.79.text:
in the Low Great Chamber where the family
dined, the dining room as it’s still set

460.44.text:
up as. And he obviously had a premonition
and he said, I want… He asked his agent

468.74.text:
to hang this portrait next to the portrait
of his mother, which is exactly the same size

474.21.text:
which is at Chatsworth, and he died in the
night.

482.78.text:
This is another portrait of him with a Newfoundland
dog, and I think this shows him slightly older

489.64.text:
when he probably was at Trinity College, Cambridge,
with people like Lord Byron and he went through

499.88.text:
a huge amount of money and on being told…
His father having being told by the agent

505.72.text:
that his son was going through a vast amount
of money at Cambridge said, ‘Jolly good

510.68.text:
show, you’ll have an awful lot to spend.’
Now the focus really of this brief account

521.25.text:
is to try and tell you a bit about what the
Duke did and what… How his interest in the

531.74.text:
history of the house led to a fascination
with portrait collection and the rearrangement

538.00.text:
of it. And you see here the Great Gallery
looking south and you can see that there is

548.55.text:
the huge set of Gideon tapestries which the
National Trust is nearing completion of its

554.90.text:
restoration, conservation, but with pictures
on it in a rather spotty way now. And one

562.88.text:
of the big questions I think for the Trust
will be when the conservation of the Gideon

570.72.text:
series is finished do we put the pictures
back or should we let the pictures speak for

578.15.text:
themselves… the tapestries speak for themselves.
I know what I think, but I think we are going

584.29.text:
to have a very interesting debate about that.
Now this is… This is a record of the Gallery

595.04.text:
in its sort of first state of the Duke’s
rearrangement and you can see that this is

608.99.text:
actually… We know this is the product of
the Duke rearranging the pictures. This is

617.77.text:
his first stage of doing that. And this is
by William Henry Hunt who the Duke employed

628.31.text:
to make interior views from 1822 of several
of his houses. What has just come to light,

638.70.text:
and I’m very grateful to Charles Noble for
telling me about this, is that the 6th Duke

647.94.text:
had begun altering the picture hang as early
as 1813 and that was only two years after

653.82.text:
he inherited the dukedom.
And on the 19th of February 1813, he wrote

659.34.text:
from Hardwick to Countess Spencer, ‘Bad
weather’. He was quite interested in the

666.01.text:
weather, which I think probably was usually
bad here. ‘Bad weather gave me a long day

672.11.text:
in the house for hanging and arranging the
pictures in the gallery. It is a very difficult

677.45.text:
thing to do but I rather figure myself upon
excelling in the art’. And then a few days

684.95.text:
later he wrote again: ‘Yesterday I made
great progress in hanging my pictures. It

691.49.text:
is quite an historical gallery and a little
order in the arrangement does wonders’.

699.27.text:
And that’s really what we’re looking at,
and one of the things that you will notice

704.37.text:
in the next slides of the gallery by David
Cox who painted three large watercolours of

717.80.text:
the gallery, which are now at Chatsworth,
is that the hang is actually rather different.

724.37.text:
And, just very quickly, if I can just take
you through the statistics for picture hanging.

735.02.text:
In 1601, the pictures… There were about
80 pictures in the whole… In the gallery.

748.04.text:
And these were hung probably in the window
embrasures where there weren’t tapestries.

753.36.text:
And we think that that was also the case in
here. By 1792 there was 67 paintings hanging

764.35.text:
in the gallery, so there wasn’t a sort of
huge difference between Bess of Hardwick’s

770.05.text:
time and the late 18th century. And as David
said earlier, the relevant inventory in 1792

777.80.text:
says 28 of them were described as old pictures
much defaced. But by 1827, which is the year

786.07.text:
before this, the gallery contained 190 pictures.
So this is the 6th Duke having fun with his

795.85.text:
house really. It’s the sort of thing that
we would do if we owned Chatsworth and Hardwick.

802.37.text:
And one of the problems about dealing with
the picture hang in the gallery, if we do

809.32.text:
continue to hang pictures on the tapestries,
is that a big hang like this treats the tapestries

818.44.text:
as wallpaper, and it sort of works and is
immensely beautiful and so on and I think

823.12.text:
obviously the tapestries would have been pretty
dirty with coal dust and all sorts of thing

830.42.text:
by… By then.
And this was a… An 18th century fashion.

835.18.text:
George III went in for this, as you can see
in Pyne’s ‘Royal Residences’. But if

840.91.text:
you don’t have all these pictures and you
can’t make a great symmetrical hang and

847.30.text:
you’ve just spent 1 and a half million on
the conservation I think we may have to have

851.71.text:
a little reassessment and in fact actually
the book that we… The research for the book

856.71.text:
that we’re doing has been a very interesting
lead-in to this because we’ve started thinking

862.18.text:
afresh about how the arrangements have changed
at Hardwick. So this is looking south, and

871.29.text:
I just want you to notice there’s a window
here. This run of seat furniture is a Chatsworth

881.16.text:
but about 1740 probably, covered in several
different ways now. But apparently the Duke

888.98.text:
would be… Would be sympathetic to a request
to borrow them. And that’s another good

896.21.text:
thing, that we’ve cemented very good relations
with Chatsworth. We’ve had them before but

903.82.text:
now they’re even better.
And this… If you… One of the sad things

908.33.text:
is that the 6th Duke left one of the great
evidences for his life and his thinking and

917.10.text:
everything, is the guidebook that he wrote
in the form of a letter to one of his sisters

923.04.text:
which he had privately published in 1845 called
‘A Handbook to Chatsworth and Hardwick’

928.34.text:
and it was privately printed and it’s very
rare. But it’s full of really interesting

933.51.text:
things and one of the things he says is that
in taking people around the house he says,

940.16.text:
‘I open…’ People are getting really
rather tired and wanting their luncheon…

944.97.text:
That’s wonderful. Wanting their luncheon
and I opened the door at the bottom of the

951.21.text:
gallery and wow, they’ve forgotten that
they’re hungry and he takes them through.

957.47.text:
So whereas visitors now come from the south
end, he brought them in through the north

962.35.text:
end.
Now we’re going to look the other way. I

968.52.text:
mean incidentally I should say this is the
Lapierre… The canopy of the Lapierre state

974.91.text:
bed from Chatsworth, which in the 6th Duke’s
time was falling apart. But he rescued the

982.11.text:
canopy and hung it as a sort of coup d’oeil
in the gallery. One of the great single acts

987.76.text:
of display in country house history I think.
I think it’s a wonderful eye- catcher. So

995.65.text:
now we’re looking at the other… Towards
the other end, you can see what I mean here.

1001.93.text:
And incidentally I said that the 6th Duke
has touched almost everything. That frame

1008.10.text:
is one of the 6th Duke’s frames which you
see around the embroidered textiles, and he

1014.81.text:
calls them the ‘eternal Chatsworth mouldings’
because he demolished a section of Chatsworth

1021.21.text:
which was called the Mary Queen of Scots rooms
and had a huge amount of this moulding in

1029.83.text:
great lengths. So the 6th Duke has put his
mark on the Queen.

1037.36.text:
Now this is one… This is one of the great
watercolours of the 19th century in my view.

1046.16.text:
William Henry Hunt is… Is a very good and
very accurate delineator of interiors; extremely

1055.61.text:
competent and actually rather beautiful. But
this, when you see it in the flesh, is the

1060.69.text:
biggest watercolour that Cox ever did. And
it’s flanked… It was flanked in the exhibition

1067.94.text:
in 1840, at The Royal Society of Watercolourists,
by two others which are in the… In the Ducal

1074.06.text:
collection at Chatsworth. And they were meant
to be seen as a triptych and then there are

1082.06.text:
other versions of different views.
But here you’ve got even more pictures and

1089.90.text:
I think that the nature of the hang hand has
changed somewhat. He’s concentrating more

1095.07.text:
on the sort of pictures we’ve been talking
about and less on a rather sort of polite

1101.53.text:
hang of 18th century portraits in gilt frames.
And here’s the Henry VIII… Henry VII cartoon.

1111.42.text:
Here’s the long set of seat furniture. These
tables are made around 1600 are still in the

1121.27.text:
collection. It’s a very rare sort of table
that of the kind that was listed in the Lumley

1125.99.text:
inventory. Here is a fantastic pair of chandeliers
which I think were made in Southern Netherlands

1135.88.text:
and imported by Bess of Hardwick and I think
they must be the ones that were listed in

1142.44.text:
1601 in the Great Hall. Here’s the… Here’s
the bed but here’s the equestrian portrait

1148.82.text:
of the 1st Duke and remember that there was
a window covering half of that end wall at

1157.14.text:
both ends and he’s decided right I want
to go… I want to go really big on pictures

1164.73.text:
and so he’s blocked up the windows and relied
on the lighting from… From the side.

1173.17.text:
And incidentally you would have noticed as
you went down the stairs here that there are

1179.47.text:
some really rather good tapestries on the
staircase including the Hero and Leander set.

1185.46.text:
This is the 6th Duke’s idea, he moved them
from Chatsworth. But one of the things that

1189.94.text:
he says in 1845 in his handbook, he says tapestries
and textiles are unlike pictures which need

1198.74.text:
a side light but with textiles you have to
have a frontal light. And one rather wonders

1205.95.text:
whether he was thinking of that to some extent
by blocking up the… The end windows. I think…

1215.27.text:
The other thing David showed an… I think
yours was an engraving after, wasn’t it?

1221.92.text:
David Taylor:– Nash.
Christopher Rowell:– Nash.

1223.64.text:
David Taylor:– Yes.
Christopher Rowell:– And the date of this,

1227.91.text:
according to Cox’s biographer, Solly, is
1839 and that’s a year before Nash published

1236.41.text:
his ‘Mansions of the Olden Time’. And
this boy and the little spaniel holding a

1243.49.text:
hawk like James VI, is right out of Nash and
I think Cox is sort of paying a certain tribute

1255.96.text:
to Nash, or vying with Nash. What is really
odd and typical at the time is that the boy

1263.21.text:
of course is in Van Dyck dress and he’s
walking past a set of furniture from 1740,

1268.79.text:
but nobody really bothers about that. And
here’s… Here’s… Here are the other

1278.48.text:
two views of the gallery, which are part of
this sort of triptych. This table of around

1286.97.text:
1600, 1610 is still in the collection. This
is Christian Bruce, Countess of Devonshire’s

1293.66.text:
State Couch under the canopy, which makes
an awful lot of sense, and I think that’s

1299.16.text:
one of the things that we are rather keen
to emulate. And here’s the last one. The

1308.40.text:
south end portrait of Hobbes. This is a copy
of the Van Dyck of the 10th Earl of Northumberland

1318.31.text:
at Petworth. I didn’t know that’s still
in the collection.

1323.28.text:
And here you have probably what Bess of Hardwick
had. You’ve got the pictures in… You know,

1333.44.text:
here’s the King’s and the, sort of, famous
men portraits, which are often ludicrously

1340.64.text:
assigned to members of the family and Philip
IV of Spain is Mr Cavendish. But this must

1348.70.text:
be where the pictures hung in 1601. Perhaps
that is actually something that the Duke didn’t

1355.82.text:
change. We… I’ve only just found out that
these beautiful scarlet sun-curtains, which

1362.90.text:
Cox made such a thing of, were replacements
of a set of green sun-curtains that were there

1373.39.text:
before. And you know, this was of ineffable
beauty this room, and one can’t really go

1381.54.text:
back to it, I suspect because we don’t have
the same number of pictures and we’ve got

1386.27.text:
the tapestry issue.
Now I just have to touch on this wonderful

1393.35.text:
fantasy of Mary Queen of Scots. This is her
statue by Sir Richard Westmacott, which the

1401.40.text:
Duke commissioned. I think possibly because
Westmacott had done a statue of Elizabeth

1407.64.text:
I for Harrow School in 1818. And what’s
rather amusing is that one of… He records

1416.30.text:
in his handbook in 1845 that his prime sources
were the tomb… In Westminster Abbey and

1424.23.text:
a portrait, which was then… Which was until
recently attributed to Zuccaro but which is

1432.60.text:
now thought to be Spanish school which purported
to be of Mary Queens of Scots but in fact

1441.09.text:
is of an unknown noble women probably connected
with the family of Palma in Italy.

1448.33.text:
So it’s rather strange that this was…
That this statue was partly based on a portrait

1456.56.text:
that wasn’t Mary Queen of Scots. But that
isn’t really the point because the Duke

1461.67.text:
knew that Mary Queen of Scots had been executed
long before Hardwick was finished. But he

1469.06.text:
originally commissioned this for Chatsworth
but thought it would be amusing to bring it

1472.77.text:
here. And of course people trooped around
this house thinking that everything, you know,

1477.19.text:
that this was Mary Queen of Scots canopy and
so on. It was a sort of, these were the chairs

1481.60.text:
and the bed and everything. So that was an
important part of his presentation of the

1489.67.text:
house.
Now I’m just going to end by… This isn’t

1494.91.text:
really so much on the 6th Duke, but one of
the things I’ve been writing about for the

1501.15.text:
book is picture frames. And it’s rather
convenient that actually you’ve just seen

1509.79.text:
the Cox view of pictures like this hanging
very much in the same position but what I

1516.62.text:
think one can say about this collection just
as David has said yet about the fact that

1525.79.text:
here is a set of portraits that is based in
the 17th century’s largely described in

1532.50.text:
1601 and therefore its remarkable longevity
in the great tradition of the house. But these

1540.24.text:
frames I think these partly date from before
1601 and this one for example which is called

1549.26.text:
Sir Thomas Moore is in fact of someone completely
different is… Looks as though it is pear

1557.11.text:
wood, which has been blackened because you
can see the pear wood coming through. This

1564.34.text:
is a typical sort of frame of the period.
The National Portrait Gallery, for example,

1569.96.text:
has… Jacob Simon has published alot about
similar frames, which were essentially of

1576.30.text:
the Italian cassetta style. And in Hardwick
they’re either plain black or they have

1581.44.text:
this black with sort of gilt inner sight moulding.
And of course there are later frames here.

1595.98.text:
There’s going to be a conference on Auricular
Frames at the Wallace Collection in… I think

1600.56.text:
it’s the 8th and 9th of October. But here
are some rather interesting frames. This is

1606.18.text:
around 1642 and this one getting more elaborate
and rather flatter is around 1650. And they’re

1618.38.text:
sort of comparable to portraits for example
at Ham House that have similar frames.

1624.43.text:
But I just want to end by throwing a fly across
the water, as it were, and seeing what you

1633.16.text:
think about this. But I was looking at this,
really, in relation to the frame, which is

1641.50.text:
the grandest frame at Hardwick. We thought
initially it was French but in fact it’s

1646.08.text:
probably English in the French manner and
this is Catherine [Caroline] of Ansbach with

1651.74.text:
her… One of her sons, the Duke of Cumberland.
And we were looking at… David and I and

1657.15.text:
a one or two other people were looking at
it, and I suddenly thought, because I happen

1661.46.text:
to be the world expert on this very important
artist called Isaac Whood, and nobody else

1668.36.text:
has written anything about it really. And
there are some records in the Heinz Archive,

1674.23.text:
but in terms of publications. I got interested
in this because there’s a whole series of

1680.19.text:
pictures at Winchester College. Just go forward.
Of young noble men in the 1730s, and this

1693.76.text:
one on the right is the future 9th Earl of
Exeter who… Who’s… Look, here’s Whood’s

1705.58.text:
signature, and the set at Winchester is actually
really quite different in some ways. But Whood

1711.80.text:
was a chameleon; he copied and employed drapery
painters and so on.

1718.28.text:
So in the end, the lots of advice from various
people, I concluded and published that the

1725.16.text:
series at Winchester as by Isaac Whood all
of them. But just looking at this, there is

1733.09.text:
something not Amigoni-like, or even William
Aikman-like, because this family group is

1744.61.text:
a Chatsworth by Aikman, who was patronized
extensively by the Queen. And although there

1752.71.text:
are certain similarities, this is the same
sitter. He’s rather older for a start but

1761.47.text:
Charles Noble feels that this is a different
hand. He’s less sure about Isaac Whood for

1769.65.text:
the other, but I just put that forward as
a rather interesting idea and it was a rather

1776.83.text:
unexpected bonus of actually looking again
at the things in the collection. So anyway,

1781.93.text:
it’s a rather quick run through a lot of
history and I hope I haven’t outstayed my
